author: By Charlie Warzel
title: He Quit the Internet 2 Months Before the Pandemic
description: When Aron Rosenberg decided to try living offline for a year, he thought his sabbatical might be painful. It turned out to be easier than his return.
content: Aron Rosenberg was on a road trip last summer when he realized his mind wasn’t working the way it used to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Myanmar’s unrepentant, brutal military.
content: Since a coup last month, the Tatmadaw, as the military in Myanmar is known, is now fully back in charge, and its brutal practices are being watched with horror by the rest of the world. It recently turned its guns on the masses in response to a nationwide civil disobedience movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim
title: The Dangerous Job of Making Deliveries in N.Y.C.
description: As demand skyrocketed during the pandemic,  robberies and violent assaults increased against the people bringing food to customers' homes.

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Will Pay More for U.S. Troop Presence
description: South Korea has agreed to increase its payment for the upkeep of American troops by 13.9 percent this year. The deal removes a major thorn in the alliance.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea said on Wednesday that it had agreed to increase its share in covering the cost of the American military presence by 13.9 percent this year, removing a prolonged dispute in the alliance ahead of a joint visit by Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Like Some Shrimp and Jets
description: Nancy Stark and Will Nediger serve up a delicious Wednesday puzzle.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — What a joy of a puzzle we have today! This is Nancy Stark and Will Nediger’s fifth collaboration, and they clearly have a formula that works. There were so many standout clues in this puzzle, but I especially wanted to point out the symmetrical IRISH PUBS and SPORTS BAR at 10-Down and 32-Down, which put a big smile on my face when I filled them both in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Nostalgia, One Year In
description: The extraordinary allure of ordinary people.
content: Want to get the At Home newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Major Food Group Returns to the Old Neighborhood
description: Rich Torrisi, Mario Carbone and Jeff Zalaznick will open a restaurant in the Puck Building loosely based on Torrisi Italian Specialties.
content: Having planted their flag all over the city, Rich Torrisi, Mario Carbone and Jeff Zalaznick, the restaurateurs behind Major Food Group, are going back to their roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Black and Hispanic Communities Grapple With Vaccine Misinformation
description: The false information arrives on social media and fringe news sites, influencing people already facing other hurdles to getting vaccinated. Some activists are going door to door to counter it.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — On an unseasonably warm day in February, two men working with a local community group went door to door in an ethnically diverse neighborhood to persuade people to sign up for Covid-19 vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: What Can Biden’s Plan Do for Poverty? Look to Bangladesh.
description: As that nation turns 50, its surprising success offers lessons about investing in the most marginalized.
content: One of the great moral stains on the United States is that the richest and most powerful country in history has accepted staggering levels of child poverty. With final legislative approval of President Biden’s $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan on Wednesday, the United States has decided to scrub at that stain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Who Made My Crossword?
description: This month’s spotlight shines on Soleil Saint-Cyr.
content: Editor’s note: Ms. Saint-Cyr, who made her New York Times Crossword debut on Feb. 1 at age 17, is the youngest woman to have a puzzle published in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: The key to President Biden’s successful vaccination campaign? Underpromise and overdeliver.
description: When President Biden pledged last week to amass enough shots by late May to inoculate every American adult, the pronouncement was greeted as a triumphant acceleration of a vaccination campaign that seemed only weeks earlier to be faltering.
content: When President Biden pledged last week to amass enough shots by late May to inoculate every American adult, the pronouncement was greeted as a triumphant acceleration of a vaccination campaign that seemed only weeks earlier to be faltering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Despite Pandemic, 300,000 Expected at Florida Motorcycle Rally
description: Bike Week typically draws a half-million people to the Daytona Beach area, but a smaller crowd is expected this year. Still, some worry that it could be a superspreader event.
content: About 300,000 people are expected to descend on Daytona Beach, Fla., this week for a large annual motorcycle rally called Bike Week that is taking place during a pandemic in a state with few restrictions to slow its spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Recall of Kia Vehicles Comes With a Special Caution: Don’t Park in the Garage
description: A concern over fire risk for nearly 380,000 Kia Sportage and Cadenza vehicles is underscored by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
content: In the realm of consumer alerts, the advisory Tuesday from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration about a recall of nearly 380,000 Kia vehicles was the equivalent of a flashing dashboard light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Biden Got the Vaccine Rollout Humming, With Trump’s Help
description: Trump administration officials grumble that they laid the groundwork for surging vaccinations, but some hard work in the trenches has helped pick up the pace of production.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden pledged last week to amass enough vaccine by late May to inoculate every adult in the United States, the pronouncement was greeted as a triumphant acceleration of a vaccination campaign that seemed to be faltering only weeks earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Congress Clears $1.9 Trillion Aid Bill, Sending It to Biden
description: The sweeping legislation had no support from Republican lawmakers, who called it bloated and unaffordable. It will deliver emergency aid and broader assistance to low- and middle-income Americans.
content: WASHINGTON — Congress gave final approval on Wednesday to President Biden’s sweeping, nearly $1.9 trillion stimulus package, as Democrats acted over unified Republican opposition to push through an emergency pandemic aid plan that carries out a vast expansion of the country’s social safety net.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Tanier
title: In N.F.L. Free Agency, Your Team Either Goes Broke or Stinks
description: G.M.s will have to work extra hard to add talent in a salary cap-crunched 2021. It’s still a bad way for most teams to improve.
content: Welcome to the start of N.F.L. free agency, one of the most exciting events of the league’s off-season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Isabella Kwai
title: Under Fire Over Race, British Media Admit There Might be a Problem
description: The fallout from the Harry and Meghan interview created a rare public schism in the press, and an embarrassing reversal, and raised broader questions about racism in Britain.
content: LONDON — In the wake of Harry and Meghan’s explosive interview, an influential professional society speaking for the British news media issued a defiant response, rejecting the idea of racism and intolerance in British coverage of the couple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How to Reach the Unvaccinated
description: To counter online misinformation, it helps to knock on doors.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Yankees Will Have to Get Creative in Zack Britton’s Absence
description: A reliable lefty and a vocal leader, Britton has been the team’s rock since his arrival. Elbow surgery has put him out for a few months.
content: The Yankees acquired Zack Britton in a trade with the Baltimore Orioles on July 24, 2018. Two days later, he made his first appearance in pinstripes, and soon became a mainstay in the bullpen and a leading voice in the clubhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Steven Lee Myers
title: Xi’s Gambit: China Plans for a World Without American Technology
description: Beijing’s leaders plot a path to go it alone, vowing to spend big to fill gaps in innovation and avoid dependence on the United States and others.
content: China is freeing up tens of billions of dollars for its tech industry to borrow. It is cataloging the sectors where the United States or others could cut off access to crucial technologies. And when its leaders released their most important economic plans last week, they laid out their ambitions to become an innovation superpower beholden to none.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Roblox Tops $45 Billion on First Day of Trading as Gaming Booms
description: The gaming site, valued at $4 billion a year ago, has benefited from the way children are passing their time in the pandemic.
content: When the pandemic forced people indoors a year ago, many passed the time by playing games on their iPhones, building gaming computers and exploring the latest blockbuster titles on their Xbox and PlayStation consoles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Gilbertson
title: A City Strapped: Photographing a New York in Need
description: The pandemic shattered the city’s economy, affecting people’s homes, livelihoods and wallets. One photojournalist documented the hardships, as both a lament and a tribute.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Snowflakes as You’ve Never Seen Them Before
description: Whether made with setups using sapphire and carbon fiber or an old mitten and a standard camera, these photographic approaches allow close-ups of the tiny masterpieces formed when snow falls.
content: Sextillions of snowflakes fell from the sky this winter. That’s billions of trillions of them, now mostly melted away as spring approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reluctantly, a Coal State Pivots to Wind
description: Wyoming shows how energy transformation in the United States is possible
content: Generations of Wyoming residents found a steady paycheck in coal mines and took pride in powering the nation. But now, it’s energy from the region’s other abundant energy resource, wind, that’s creating jobs and much-needed tax revenues in one county.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: PGA Tour Is About to Admit Its Largest Crowd of the Year
description: The Players Championship plans to welcome 10,000 spectators each day, and the golfers hope they don’t gather around the 18th hole all at once.
content: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — After eight months of hosting events without fans, the PGA Tour recently began cautiously welcoming back a limited number of spectators to its tournaments. This week, at the celebrated Players Championship in northeast Florida, the tour will take a leap with as many as 10,000 fans on the grounds, the most for any event this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Why Are We So Obsessed With Royalty?
description: Monarchies are surprisingly resilient, in real life and popular culture. Are we hard-wired to respect the throne?
content: My 4-year-old daughter is into princesses. Really into princesses. I have given the Princess Industrial Complex more money than I’d like to admit to keep those episodes of “Elena of Avalor” coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Court Dismisses Trump Campaign’s Defamation Suit Against New York Times
description: A New York State judge ruled that the opinion essay at the center of the suit was constitutionally protected speech.
content: A New York State court on Tuesday dismissed a defamation lawsuit filed by the re-election campaign of Donald J. Trump against The New York Times Company, ruling that an opinion essay that argued there had been a “quid pro quo” between the candidate and Russian officials before the 2016 presidential election was protected speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Harlan Coben, Suburban Dad With 75 Million Books in Print
description: With a 33rd novel on the way and deals with Netflix, Amazon and Apple, the prolific author writes in Ubers, at Stop & Shop and just about anywhere else he can.
content: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. — The thriller writer Harlan Coben has some free advice for anyone who cares to ask: “If it produces pages: good. If it doesn’t produce pages: bad.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China and Russia Agree to Explore the Moon Together
description: The two countries, moving increasingly closer, signed a memorandum of agreement to collaborate on lunar missions, including the establishment of a research station in orbit or on the surface of the moon.
content: China and Russia have agreed to jointly build a research station on or around the moon, setting the stage for a new space race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Marcia Fudge, Biden’s Pick to Lead HUD, Is Confirmed by Senate
description: Ms. Fudge faces as tough a task as any cabinet secretary: rebuilding a neglected agency central to the fight against racial inequity and poverty.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Marcia L. Fudge of Ohio was confirmed as secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development on Wednesday, becoming the first Black woman in decades to run an agency that will be at the forefront of the Biden administration’s efforts to fight racial inequity and poverty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Politicians Tread Carefully in Minefield Left by Harry and Meghan’s Interview
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has yet to comment on a bombshell that has rocked the monarchy, jolted the Commonwealth and divided British society.
content: More than 11 million people in Britain tuned into Oprah Winfrey’s interview with Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan. Fallout from the interview has reverberated globally, raising sensitive issues of race, rocking the royal family, upsetting the Commonwealth and exposing a sharp generational divide over the future of the British monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Is a Long-Dismissed Forgery Actually the Oldest Known Biblical Manuscript?
description: In 1883, a manuscript found near the Dead Sea caused an international sensation. It was denounced as a fake, and soon vanished. But what if it was the only known source text for the Hebrew Bible?
content: In 1883, a Jerusalem antiquities dealer named Moses Wilhelm Shapira announced the discovery of a remarkable artifact: 15 manuscript fragments, supposedly discovered in a cave near the Dead Sea. Blackened with a pitchlike substance, their paleo-Hebrew script nearly illegible, they contained what Shapira claimed was the “original” Book of Deuteronomy, perhaps even Moses’ own copy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The Conspiracy Threatening a $360 Million TV Deal
description: A feud between a top Turkish soccer team and the league’s broadcaster is rooted in taped chants, time stamps and club rivalry. But the fight’s cost could be enormous.
content: The offending chant had been broadcast during Turkish league matches for months before anyone noticed it. The refrain, a variation of which is often heard in stadiums around Turkey, ends with a profanity directed at Fenerbahce, one of the country’s biggest and richest clubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Royals’ Interview Response Rings Hollow to Late-Night Hosts
description: Stephen Colbert was puzzled by the British monarchy’s concern about being seen as out of touch: “Because if there’s one thing the palace surrounded by iron spikes looked like before, it was ‘in touch.’”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Decorate Your New Home Before You Move
description: Measuring, design and shopping tools built into smartphone apps can help you get your next house in order.
content: Moving in a pandemic has special challenges — especially if your new place is across the country and you can’t make repeated visits to gradually set things up. And shopping for furniture in crowded stores may make some people uneasy while the Covid-19 vaccines are still being distributed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: How to Apologize to Your Kids
description: Everyone snaps sometimes — it’s what you do after that counts.
content: A year into working from my bedroom, I thought I had reached an emotional equilibrium where I could tolerate the multiple kid interruptions throughout my day. But last week, my older daughter was assigned a scavenger hunt in remote school. She barged through my door — which I am sorry to report has no lock — four times in one hour, looking for slippers, something red (twice) and a hairbrush. On the fourth interruption, I snapped. “You’ve got to get out of here,” I said, in a voice much harsher than I like to use with my children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: One Year Later, Rudy Gobert Is at Peace. And Thriving.
description: The Utah Jazz center’s positive test for the coronavirus began a cascading shutdown of American sports. But with a huge new contract and a dominant team, he has moved on.
content: It was not a time in his life, understandably, that Rudy Gobert is eager to revisit. No one wants to be connected so closely to the day that the N.B.A., suddenly infiltrated by the coronavirus, suspended its season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: He Owns World Famous Stamps and a Prized Coin. Now He’s Selling.
description: Stuart Weitzman, who made his fortune in shoes, is parting with three of his collecting triumphs, including a block of four “Inverted Jennies.”
content: On the day in 1918 when the Postal Service began selling stamps with an image of a newfangled airplane, a 29-year-old stockbroker’s clerk and stamp collector went out on his lunch hour to buy some. He emerged from the nearest post office with a single sheet of 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Quealy and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Obamacare’s About to Get a Lot More Affordable. These Maps Show How.
description: For this year and next, the stimulus bill boosts subsidies for nearly all those buying their own coverage, making insurance free for more people and giving higher-income people discounts for the first time.
content: Under the stimulus bill passed by Congress this week and set to be signed by President Biden on Friday, nearly all those who buy their own insurance are eligible for a discount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: A no-recipe recipe for pasta with brussels sprouts and diced bacon is just the thing for your weeknight feed.
content: Good morning. I’ve been talking a lot about no-recipe recipes recently, in advance of the publication of “New York Times Cooking: No-Recipe Recipes” next week, and my colleague Tina Jordan reached out to me the other day with a stellar one. It’s for a fiery weeknight pasta dish with brussels sprouts and diced bacon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Maywood, N.J.: A Close-Knit Community With a Quaint Downtown
description: With its walkable streets and proximity to Manhattan, the borough is an appealing place to live. But good luck finding a house for sale this spring.
content: Beata Piszczek has had some lucky breaks, starting in 1994 when she won Poland’s green card lottery, providing the ticket for her family to come to the United States, and again last year, when she landed her dream house in Maywood, N.J., just a block from the borough’s downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Markie in Milwaukee’ Review: Acknowledging Painful Transitions
description: This documentary presents a portrait of a transgender woman’s life, her faith as an Evangelical Christian and her strained relationship with her family.
content: When the documentary “Markie in Milwaukee” begins, Markie Wenzel, a middle-aged transgender woman, is in the process of eradicating the records of her own existence. When we meet her, nearly a decade ago, she’s beginning the process of “detransitioning,” which in her case meant legally changing her name, discarding her hormone treatments and wearing men’s clothes in public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Police Officer Is Arrested Over London Woman’s Disappearance
description: The officer is being held on suspicion of murder in connection with the disappearance of Sarah Everard, 33, who went missing after leaving a friend’s house, the police said.
content: LONDON — A police officer is being held on suspicion of murder in connection with the disappearance of a woman who went missing last week as she was on her way home in South London, the police said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Georgia Sheriff Reopens Case Into Teenager Found Dead in a Gym Mat
description: The body of Kendrick Johnson, 17, was found upside-down in a large mat in his high school gym in 2013. The county sheriff said the death, initially ruled an accident, should be investigated again.
content: When Kendrick Johnson of Valdosta, Ga., didn’t come home the night of Jan. 10, 2013, his family called the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Senate Confirms Biden’s Pick to Lead E.P.A.
description: Michael S. Regan has said he intends to act aggressively in carrying out the president’s agenda of fighting climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday confirmed Michael S. Regan, the former top environmental regulator for North Carolina, to lead the Environmental Protection Agency and drive some of the Biden administration’s biggest climate and regulatory policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: I’m So Sorry! Romance Novels, Bad Behavior and Forgiveness
description: Four new novels bring readers the Happily Ever After they expect — but not in predictable ways.
content: A romance’s happy ending requires that neither of the lead characters do anything unforgivable. But everyone’s definition of unforgivable is different — so if a character does something a reader considers wildly out of bounds, or if a character’s remorse is not finely calibrated enough for the reader’s taste, it can call the author’s whole definition of happiness into question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A New ‘Aida’ Lands in the Middle of France’s Culture Wars
description: The production, which examines the work’s colonial legacy, opened after the far right accused the Paris Opera of “antiracism gone mad.”
content: When Lotte de Beer’s new production of Verdi’s “Aida” recently premiered at the Paris Opera — not to a full house, but to an audience online — she was just relieved it was happening.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘How Beautiful We Were,’ by Imbolo Mbue: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “How Beautiful We Were,” by Imbolo Mbue
content: We should have known the end was near. How could we not have known? When the sky began to pour acid and rivers began to turn green, we should have known our land would soon be dead. Then again, how could we have known when they didn’t want us to know? When we began to wobble and stagger, tumbling and snapping like feeble little branches, they told us it would soon be over, that we would all be well in no time. They asked us to come to village meetings, to talk about it. They told us we had to trust them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: In ‘Fulfillment,’ One-Click Shopping Is Cheap, Easy and Economically Unsustainable
description: The journalist Alec MacGillis argues that Amazon is the engine behind regional inequality that has made parts of the country “incomprehensible to one another.”
content: To hear him tell it, Jeff Bezos loves stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: What happened on the first day of jury selection at the Derek Chauvin trial?
description: The first three jurors were selected on Tuesday, with one saying he was not “scared to take on a trial of this magnitude.”
content: The first three jurors were selected on Tuesday for the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer accused of second-degree murder in the death of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Covid-19 Devastated Many Communities. But Not Cherokee Nation.
description: It all starts with universal health care and a history of self-reliance.
content: The Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma has kept its Covid death rate lower than most American communities’ — even though Native Americans are almost twice as likely to die from Covid-19 as white people are. In this video, we uncover the secret to the Cherokees’ success. But it’s not exactly rocket science. It’s really just a smart, slow but steady commitment to universal health care. Oh, and a long history of having to be self-reliant when the U.S. government fails to step up and provide support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: Tasmanian Tigers Are Extinct. Why Do People Keep Seeing Them?
description: Quirks of the human mind and how we process information might explain the uncanny appearances of thylacines.
content: The Tasmanian tiger is still extinct. Reports of its enduring survival are greatly exaggerated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Los Angeles Schools and Teachers’ Union Agree to Reopen Classrooms
description: The nation’s second-largest school district is expected to start offering in-person instruction to elementary school and high-need students in about six weeks.
content: The Los Angeles Unified School District and its teachers’ union have reached a tentative agreement to restore in-person instruction, clearing the way for a mid-April reopening of some classrooms in one of the last large school districts to bring students back in substantial numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Should the Government Provide a Guaranteed Income for Families With Children?
description: A child benefit plan in President Biden’s $1.9 trillion pandemic relief bill would give monthly checks to families with children. Do you think this plan should become permanent?
content: According to the government definition of poverty, about 10 million children in the United States fall under this category. Does that surprise you? How does knowing this make you feel?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chye-Ching Huang
title: How Biden Funds His Next Bill: Shrink the $7.5 Trillion Tax Gap
description: The I.R.S. is often unable to detect or fight blatant tax cheating by the rich and big businesses. Restoring the missing revenue is a solution that pays for itself.
content: With the passage of a deficit-financed $1.9 trillion relief bill just hours away, Democrats in Congress may soon pivot to new agenda items, including President Biden’s Build Back Better plan for infrastructure and other critical investments. And those lawmakers will inevitably face intense pressure from fiscal moderates to include tax “pay fors” in spending legislation. One of the best ways to raise plenty of revenue — and help honest taxpayers — is to effectively battle tax cheats. To do that, though, Mr. Biden and Congress must seize the chance to revamp and restore the federal government’s own infrastructure: the Internal Revenue Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Sets Salary Cap at $182.5 Million in 2021
description: The figure is down 8 percent from 2020, an anticipated decline based on revenue lost because of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The N.F.L. has determined the salary cap for the 2021 season, saying each team will have $182.5 million to spend on player payroll, nearly 8 percent less than in 2020, when revenues were cleaved by the coronavirus pandemic. In 2020, the salary cap was $198.2 million, a league record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Cancel America’s Student Loan Debt! But How?
description: It’s a trillion-dollar crisis that’s crippling the economy and dooming millions of college graduates. So what’s the fairest way to fix it?
content: The problem of student loan debt has reached crisis proportions. As a college degree has grown increasingly necessary for economic mobility, so has the $1.7 trillion in student loan debt that Americans have taken on to access that opportunity. President Biden has put some debt cancellation on the table, but progressive Democrats are pushing him for more. So what is the fairest way to correct course?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Rise of an Antitrust Pioneer
description: Lina Khan would bring another progressive voice to competition oversight.
content: Word that the White House plans to pick Lina Khan, a Columbia Law professor whose research has spurred a rethinking of competition law, for a seat on the Federal Trade Commission has Washington and business types speculating that the Biden administration is preparing to get tough on antitrust. (She would need to be confirmed by the Senate.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, James Dobbins and Maria Jimenez Moya
title: With Texas’ Mask Mandate Over, Workers Worry About Encroaching Virus
description: Gov. Greg Abbott cited personal freedom and economic pain while relaxing coronavirus restrictions. But many are upset, especially those who take precautions and work with the public.
content: HOUSTON — As rules that had been in place for months were relaxed across Texas on Wednesday, plexiglass barriers came down, tables were added onto the floors of restaurants and signs requiring masks were removed from the front doors of businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: With House passage, Congress clears the nearly $1.9 trillion stimulus plan for President Biden’s signature.
description: Democrats acted over unified Republican opposition to push through an emergency pandemic aid plan that included a vast expansion of the country’s social safety net.
content: Congress gave final approval on Wednesday to President Biden’s sweeping, nearly $1.9 trillion stimulus package, as Democrats acted over unified Republican opposition to push through an emergency pandemic aid plan that carries out a vast expansion of the country’s social safety net.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Ballet Is Hard Enough. What Happens When You Lose a Year?
description: An elite male principal. A veteran ballerina. A rising apprentice. Three dancers talk about life and work during the pandemic.
content: In ballet when you lose a year, you lose a lot. It takes years of sacrifice and training to become a professional, and the performing life of a dancer is short.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Elizabeth Dias
title: Beth Moore, a Prominent Evangelical, Splits With Southern Baptists
description: A teacher on biblical topics, she cited the “staggering” disorientation of seeing denominational leaders support Donald J. Trump, among other issues.
content: From the outside, the marriage of convenience between white conservative Christians and Donald J. Trump looked like a devoted one: White evangelicals voted for Mr. Trump overwhelmingly in 2016 and stuck with him in 2020, brushing aside perpetual lies and sexual impropriety to support a man they saw as their protector.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: For Creators, Everything Is for Sale
description: Digital stars are coming up with new ways to make money. Yet fans still hold the power.
content: A rash of new start-ups are making it easier for digital creators to monetize every aspect of their life — down to what they eat, who they hang out with and who they respond to on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Colombian Official Refuses to Say if Children Were Killed in Attack on Rebels
description: Youths were present, the defense minister said, calling them “machines of war,” but he would not give the ages of the dead. Reports that minors were killed outraged a war-weary public.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Colombia’s defense minister said Wednesday that several young people were at a rebel camp recently attacked by the military, but would not confirm reports that children were among those killed, an allegation that fueled deep outrage in a nation reeling from decades of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: New Stimulus Package Brings Big Benefits to the Middle Class
description: Be it child care or health care, an array of tax changes and subsidies makes the $1.9 trillion relief legislation more than a lifeline for the poor.
content: WASHINGTON — The economic relief plan that is headed to President Biden’s desk has been billed as the United States’ most ambitious antipoverty initiative in a generation. But inside the $1.9 trillion package, there are plenty of perks for the middle class, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 13 Spring Recipes to Add to Your Cooking List
description: Celebrate the season’s arrival with dishes that make the most of its best and brightest produce.
content: The arrival of spring is always a most-welcome event, but, this year, its approach feels even more deserving of celebration. In honor of the warmer weather, bright blooms and vibrant farmers’ markets on the horizon, you can and should make these ultimate spring dishes from NYT Cooking, which make the most of the season’s verdant produce — and scream “Spring is here!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: Louis Valray Made Only 2 Movies. But Both Are Incredible.
description: After “La Belle de Nuit” and “Escale,” the French director went on to become an engineer and died in obscurity. A virtual release gives these moody, sensual films new life.
content: Something old is sometimes new as with the rediscovery of French director Louis Valray (1896-1972), whose hitherto unknown films enrich the era of Jean Vigo, Jean Renoir, Sacha Guitry and Marcel Carné.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Sickle Cell Treatment Not Linked to Cancer, Researchers Say
description: Trials of experimental gene therapy for sickle cell disease were halted when patients developed worrying illnesses.
content: Just a few weeks after a promising gene therapy for sickle cell disease seemed to have hit a roadblock, prospects for the treatment now look better. Preliminary data suggesting that it might cause cancer have not held up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What to Know About Newsom’s State of the State
description: Wednesday: The governor made the case that California is nearly through a crisis. And that he led the state through. Also: Bagel discourse.

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Piers Morgan Leaves ‘Good Morning Britain’ After Attacks on Meghan
description: The television anchor stormed off the set of an ITV news program after his co-host, Alex Beresford, criticized his remarks about the Duchess of Sussex.
content: Piers Morgan, who drew intense scorn in Britain for his upbraiding of Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, since her bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey, resigned on Tuesday as an anchor for ITV news after storming off the set of the network’s morning show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: There Will Be Marathons This Fall. But What Will They Look Like?
description: The coronavirus pandemic has wiped out most major road races through this spring. Marathon organizers are hoping their events can return this fall with new protocols and precautions.
content: It is a tradition as much a part of the New York City Marathon as the 26.2-mile distance. The singular boom of a cannon — and the start of Frank Sinatra’s “Theme From New York, New York” — sending thousands of runners across the start line and over the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Paper Source’s Bankruptcy Leaves Female Cardmakers Feeling Burned
description: The chain’s vendors, most of them small-business owners, say they are worried they won’t be paid for orders delivered in the weeks just before the filing.
content: “Hell hath no fury like a stationer scorned.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: A $22,368 Bill That Dodged and Weaved to Find a Gap in America’s Health System
description: Bad news for one unlucky patient is also a stark example of how dysfunctional U.S. health coverage can be.
content: John Druschitz spent five days in a Texas hospital last April with fever and shortness of breath. It was still the early days of the pandemic, and doctors puzzled over a diagnosis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: New Zealand and Luna Rossa Each Score a Win on First Day of America’s Cup
description: An easy victory in the first leg by Emirates Team New Zealand stoked fears of a blowout, but Luna Rossa Prada Pirelli’s strong start in the second leg allowed it to tie things up.
content: After a series of preliminary races dominated by Italy, the America’s Cup began in earnest off Auckland, New Zealand, with much more competitive racing on Wednesday. After the first two legs, the challenger, Italy, and the Cup holder, New Zealand, were tied at one race each.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Getting to the Bottom of the Runner’s High
description: For years we’ve been crediting endorphins, but it’s really about the endocannabinoids.
content: We can stop crediting endorphins, the natural opioid painkillers produced by our bodies, for the floaty euphoria we often feel during aerobic exercise, according to a nifty new study of men, women and treadmills. In the study, runners developed a gentle intoxication, known as a runner’s high, even if researchers had blocked their bodies’ ability to respond to endorphins, suggesting that those substances could not be behind the buzz. Instead, the study suggests, a different set of biochemicals resembling internally homegrown versions of cannabis, better known as marijuana, are likely to be responsible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: On Covid Relief, Democrats Deserve a Victory Lap
description: A giant aid package is what the country badly needed and what voters wanted.
content: President Biden made it clear that he wanted to move fast and go big to deliver emergency aid to a nation reeling from the coronavirus pandemic. On Friday, he will realize this goal with the signing of the American Rescue Plan, a sweeping, $1.9 trillion aid package aimed at rescuing the nation from its pandemic slump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Biden’s nominees for top posts at the Justice Dept. vow to restore order there.
description: President Biden’s nominees to fill out the Justice Department’s leadership ranks pledged at their confirmation hearing on Tuesday to tackle domestic extremism, racial inequality and other thorny issues within the bounds of the law, seeking to restore order to a department battered by political attacks during the Trump administration.
content: President Biden’s nominees to fill out the Justice Department’s leadership ranks pledged at their confirmation hearing on Tuesday to tackle domestic extremism, racial inequality and other thorny issues within the bounds of the law, seeking to restore order to a department battered by political attacks during the Trump administration.

author: By Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Plans Messaging Blitz to Sell Economic Aid Plan
description: Drawing on a lesson from early in the Obama administration, the White House wants to tell voters how the legislation will help them and keep Republicans from defining it on their terms.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden is planning an aggressive campaign to tell voters about the benefits for them in the $1.9 trillion economic relief package that won final congressional approval on Wednesday, an attempt to ensure that he and his fellow Democrats get full political credit for the first big victory of his administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diane McWhorter and Damon Winter
title: Why Is Space Command Moving Into Mo Brooks’s Backyard?
description: The congressman from Huntsville, Ala., was quick to claim that the 2020 election was stolen. His district continues to get special treatment.
content: As uncommon as it is for the White House to worry about where the Pentagon puts its people and hardware, President Biden may need to follow the example of his predecessor and take a hard look at the site selection for U.S. Space Command. It tells a tale of two cities, Colorado Springs and Huntsville, Ala., and reveals a lot about our modern-day season of stunt guillotines and Trumpist revolutionaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Biden Nominees Vow to Avoid Politicizing Justice Dept.
description: The president’s picks for the department’s No. 2 and 3 spots pledged to restore independence to law enforcement.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s nominees to fill out the Justice Department’s leadership ranks pledged at their confirmation hearing on Tuesday to tackle domestic extremism, racial inequality and other thorny issues within the bounds of the law, seeking to restore order to a department battered by political attacks during the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Amanda Rosa
title: Two variants may account for half of New York City’s virus cases, analysis finds.
description: A version of the coronavirus first discovered in Britain continues to spread, while a second is moving even more quickly. Still, cases are down in the city, and the vaccines remain effective.
content: Genetic analysis suggests that roughly half of coronavirus cases in New York City now are caused by two new forms of the pathogen, city officials reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Historic stimulus passes Congress.
content: The $1.9 trillion stimulus package, President Joe Biden’s first major legislative undertaking, won final approval in the House of Representatives on Wednesday. Mr. Biden is expected to sign the bill on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Furor in Japanese Town Casts Light on Fukushima’s Legacy
description: When a mayor volunteered his town for a study on nuclear waste, his house was firebombed, reflecting the lingering anxiety 10 years after the Fukushima disaster.
content: SUTTSU, Japan — It seemed like an easy payday. The Japanese government was conducting a study of potential locations for storing spent nuclear fuel — a review of old geological maps and research papers about local plate tectonics. It put out a call for localities to volunteer. Participating would commit them to nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Anguish, Determination, Hope: Travel Workers Despair a Lost Year
description: Six travel workers, from a cruise ship crewmember in Manila to a tour bus driver in East Jerusalem, share how the prolonged shutdown has upended their lives.
content: In 2020, governments across the world closed borders, airlines grounded flights, hotels shuttered and cruises were canceled or postponed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $1.1 Million Homes in Rhode Island, Virginia and Indiana
description: A two-bedroom condo in a Gilded Age mansion in Newport, a modernized 1945 house in Charlottesville and a Victorian in Crown Point.
content: Designed by Dudley Newton, a prolific architect in Newport, this Dutch Renaissance-style house was constructed with locally quarried granite. It dates from 1884, when it was built for the Weld family, a pedigreed clan of merchants, doctors and lawyers, many named William. (The former Massachusetts governor William F. Weld is a descendant.) From 1925 to 1972, the house was a Catholic boys’ school. Then it was converted into multifamily residences, part of a development called the De La Salle Condominiums, with eight buildings and a total of 38 units, four of which are in this structure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Two Trump stalwarts find a new cause: #FreeBritney.
description: Representatives Jim Jordan of Ohio and Matt Gaetz of Florida sent a request to the House Judiciary Committee asking for an investigation into the role of Ms. Spears’s father in controlling her assets.
content: Two Republicans who rose to prominence by defending President Trump have seized on a new issue — the battle over the legal guardianship of Britney Spears, the former teen pop star who has suffered a succession of personal, professional and financial crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: N.Y.C. public schools saw very low virus transmission as cases in the city spiked, a study says.
description: A return to in-person teaching in the nation’s largest school system did not appear to make the pandemic worse, researchers say.
content: New York City’s public schools have seen remarkably low virus transmission compared with the citywide rate of positive test results in the months since the nation’s largest school system reopened for thousands of students, according to a major new peer-reviewed study in the medical journal Pediatrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The New Hong Kong
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: China’s crackdown on Hong Kong has happened swiftly: A rising power has asserted its authority over a global financial capital, through a harsh national security law enacted last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Matthew Haag
title: Indoor dining in N.Y.C. and New Jersey can go to 50 percent on March 19, the governors say.
description: The new half-capacity limit in New Jersey also applies to casinos, salons and gyms.
content: Restaurants in New York City and New Jersey will be able to increase indoor dining to 50 percent of capacity starting March 19, the governors of New York and New Jersey said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Do You Really Need to Fly?
description: Videoconferencing is good enough to replace a lot of pointless business travel.
content: I once flew round-trip from San Francisco to London to participate in an hourlong discussion about a book. Another time it was San Francisco-Hong Kong, Hong Kong-Singapore and back again for two lunch meetings, each more lunch than meeting. I went to Atlanta once to interview an official who flaked out at the last minute. And there was that time in Miami: three days, 5,000 miles, hotel, rental car — and on the way back a sinking realization that the person I’d gone to profile was too dull for a profile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor, Stephanie Saul and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Slowly, More Students Return to Classrooms
description: A year into the pandemic, a growing number of districts — including Los Angeles — plan to open for in-person learning.
content: School reopening inched forward across the country this week, as middle school students went back to class in Chicago, and New York City announced that it would welcome tens of thousands of high school students back on March 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Whitlow Delano, Hikari Hida and Mike Ives
title: ‘There’s No Town Left’: Fukushima’s Eerie Landscapes
description: Ten years after a devastating earthquake and tsunami led to a nuclear meltdown in northern Japan, residents are readjusting to places that feel familiar and hostile at once.
content: FUKUSHIMA, Japan — After an earthquake and tsunami pummeled a nuclear plant about 12 miles from their home, Tomoko Kobayashi and her husband joined the evacuation and left their Dalmatian behind, expecting they would return home in a few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: What to Expect From the 2021 Oscar Nominations
description: It should be the most diverse Oscar lineup in ages, and history may be made in the best-director category. Still, expect some snubs and controversies.
content: In a normal year, we would have had the Oscars by now. Instead, we’re just getting started.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Aruká Juma, Last Man of His Tribe, Is Dead
description: Mr. Juma, who used the name of his people in Brazil, was in his late 80s when he died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Charles Hill, Detective Who Found ‘The Scream,’ Dies at 73
description: His investigations, often conducted under cover, led to the recovery of Munch’s masterpiece as well as stolen paintings by Vermeer and Titian.
content: Charles Hill, a Scotland Yard detective, stood inside a house in Norway and beheld the artistic treasure he had been searching for: “The Scream,” Edvard Munch’s 1893 masterpiece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Five Oklahoma Officers Charged in Shooting Death of 15-Year-Old Boy
description: First-degree manslaughter charges were brought against the police officers after body-camera footage showed them shooting Stavian Rodriguez multiple times after he dropped a gun, prosecutors said.
content: Five Oklahoma City police officers were charged with first-degree manslaughter on Wednesday after they shot and killed a 15-year-old boy who had dropped his gun on the ground, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Fear Lurks, Even as Officials Say Not to Worry
description: Prices have yet to show much movement, but the prospect of an unbridled economy’s surging back from the pandemic has unsettled the markets.
content: While the Biden administration’s ambitious effort to salve the pandemic’s deep economic wounds made its way through Congress, proponents insisted that funneling $1.9 trillion to American households and businesses wouldn’t unshackle a long-vanquished monster: inflation.

title: Quotation of the Day: Some of Canada’s Elderly Are Vaccinated but Still Confined to Home
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 10, 2021.
content: “You always hear people say, ‘Oh they lived a long life.’ Right now, they aren’t living. They are existing.”

title: The D.C.C.C. Blacklist Is No More
description: Consultants who work with challengers are no longer barred from receiving Democratic campaign money.
content: When she challenged Representative Joe Crowley in 2018, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez did it by knocking on over 100,000 doors in her New York City district, calling even more people’s phones, and sending out still more text messages.

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden announces his intention to secure another 100 million doses of Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine.
description: President Biden said on Wednesday that he was directing the federal government to secure an additional 100 million doses of Johnson & Johnson’s Covid-19 single-shot vaccine, a move the White House said could help the country vaccinate children and, if necessary, administer booster doses or reformulate the vaccine to combat emerging variants of the virus.

title: Police Unions Won Power Using His Playbook. Now He’s Negotiating the Backlash.
description: As officer perks and protections draw new scrutiny, an architect of longtime police bargaining tactics says unions are at risk of losing it all.
content: Ron DeLord, a fiery former Texas cop turned labor organizer, has long taught union leaders how to gain power and not let go. He has likened a police union going after an elected official to a cheetah devouring a wildebeest, and suggested that taking down just one would make others fall in line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: California’s Ethnic Studies Follies
description: A proposed curriculum magnifies differences, encourages tribal loyalties and advances ideological group think.
content: The first time California’s Department of Education published a draft of an ethnic studies “model curriculum” for high school students, in 2019, it managed the neat trick of omitting anti-Semitism while committing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Arts for the Virus-Tested: The Shed Plans a Cautious Reopening
description: Music and comedy will be on tap for limited audiences in April when Renée Fleming, Michelle Wolf, Kelsey Lu and the New York Philharmonic appear.
content: The New York City arts scene is about to pass another milestone on the road to reopening: The Shed, a large performing arts venue in Hudson Yards, said Wednesday that it would hold a series of indoor performances next month for limited audiences in which everyone has either been tested for the coronavirus or vaccinated against it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: ‘A Ticking Time Bomb’: City Jails Are Crowded Again, Stoking Covid Fears
description: New York City released hundreds of people as the pandemic raged. Now jails are full again, and an increase in infections could spread the virus beyond their walls.
content: New York City’s jails were under such threat from the coronavirus last spring that city officials moved swiftly to let hundreds of people out of the crowded, airless old buildings. The effort shrank the jail population to its lowest point in more than half a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Blinken Will Meet Chinese Officials After Asia Tour Next Week
description: In his first foreign trip, the secretary of state will visit Japan and South Korea before the first in-person diplomatic encounter between the United States and China in several months.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, will meet next week with two senior Chinese government officials, the Biden administration’s first in-person diplomatic encounter with its chief foreign rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: What the $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief plan means for the pandemic.
content: The House of Representatives approved the nearly $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief plan this afternoon — a landmark moment for President Biden. The plan, which passed without any Republican votes, will send direct payments of up to $1,400 to many Americans, expand a child tax credit and extend a $300 weekly unemployment supplement. Mr. Biden is expected to sign the bill into law on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: Shinichi Sawada’s ceramic creatures; Sophie Larrimore and Jerry the Marble Faun’s two-person show; and Guadalupe Maravilla’s devotional paintings.
content: It’s hard to choose the right word to describe Shinichi Sawada’s spiky, totemic sculptures. His earth-toned ceramics — which often have horns and claws, as well as multiple faces stacked atop one another or ringing the sides — could be beasts, except they’re not very menacing. I’d say monsters, but neither do they inspire fear. They’re not quite animals or spirits. “Creatures” may be the most apt — it speaks to the interplay between natural elements and feats of imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Rafkin
title: A Former Culinary Couple Now Thrives as a Blended Family
description: For Gale Gand and Rick Tramonto, both chefs, their passion for food always came first. After their divorce, they’ve learned to prioritize family.
content: In Unhitched, couples tell the stories of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Brara
title: Two Emerging Designers Who Find Comfort in Antiquity
description: Max Zinser’s new collection of animal-like furniture and Matthew Fisher’s debut offering of marble and wood objects are both rooted in age-old crafts.
content: The designer Max Zinser, 33, got his start building sets for the fashion industry. After graduating from N.Y.U., where he studied psychology and architecture, he would take unpredictable, often chaotic, freelance jobs sourcing props (for, say, a Dutch masters-themed Valentino photo shoot) and constructing elaborate runway environments for brands including Marc Jacobs. “After a certain point, I wanted to work on projects with more permanence,” he says. But the work helped him identify a path by which he might parlay his passion for design, first nurtured during childhood — he grew up in Washington, D.C., with an architect father and a painter mother — into a profession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: On the Road Again at All-Star Weekend
description: Plenty of stars expressed concern about playing in the All-Star Game, but it proved to be an important trip for Nikola Vucevic and for a columnist eager to resume traveling.
content: Sunday’s 70th N.B.A. All-Star Game was repeatedly described as one almost all of us could have done without.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Maryland lifts many Covid restrictions, to cheers, criticism and confusion.
description: Some business owners applauded Gov. Larry Hogan’s surprise announcement this week, but some public health experts were shocked.
content: Across Maryland on Wednesday, mayors, county executives, business owners and public health officials were parsing Gov. Larry Hogan’s surprise Tuesday announcement that he was loosening statewide Covid restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Cherkis
title: What Happens to Your Mental Health When You Can’t Pay Your Rent?
description: Research suggests that increasing the minimum wage could help lower suicide rates.
content: Nearly every week for the past two years, I have gotten on the phone with a director of suicide prevention at a very large mental health system in the United States, and we review cases of suicides. For the dead, we go over their demographics, psychiatric diagnoses, how they died by suicide and all of their interactions with the mental health system, from clinic intakes to the last notes from their final therapy sessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Exports Millions of Covid Vaccine Doses Despite Supply Crunch at Home
description: The bloc has been sparring with allies over supplies of coronavirus shots and was recently accused of vaccine protectionism. But internal documents show it has exported many doses even amid its own shortages, and rollout failures.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union exported 34 million doses of coronavirus vaccines in recent weeks to dozens of countries, even as it faced shortages at home that contributed to its vaccine rollout trailing far behind drives in the United States, Britain and Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Walter LaFeber, Historian Who Dissected Diplomacy, Dies at 87
description: Challenging convention from all political perspectives, he mesmerized his students at Cornell, many of whom went on to hold foreign policy posts or professorships.
content: Walter LaFeber, a Cornell University history professor and author whose unvarnished version of American diplomacy drew hundreds of students and spectators to his Saturday morning lectures, and whose acolytes went on to influence the nation’s foreign policy, died on Tuesday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Illinois Prison Guard Pleads Guilty for Role in Beating Inmate to Death
description: Willie Hedden is one of three guards at the Western Illinois Correctional Center charged in the May 2018 assault of Larry Earvin, who was handcuffed at the time.
content: A state prison guard in Illinois pleaded guilty on Tuesday to two counts of federal civil rights violations and one count of conspiracy to engage in misleading conduct in the 2018 beating death of an inmate who had been handcuffed, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: In Australia, Hollywood Stars Have Found an Escape From the Virus. Who’s Jealous?
description: Dozens of international film productions have been lured to the country, where cases of the coronavirus are few. In turn, actors have found almost paradise.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — In the photo posted to Instagram, the actors Chris Hemsworth, Idris Elba and Matt Damon, all wearing 1980s-style sweats, embrace. They are maskless. Touching. Happy, even. The caption reads: “A little 80s themed party never did any harm!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in Mexico: A 19th-Century Courthouse Turned Hacienda
description: The oceanside city of La Paz is aiming to position itself as the mellower alternative to the beach resorts of nearby Los Cabos.
content: Since 1880, this squat white building on a bustling corner in La Paz, Mexico, has served many people in many roles. It has been a Chinese imports retail shop, a courthouse, an art gallery and, for several decades after the court moved to a modern government building, a forgotten relic. The current owner bought it in 1996 and transformed it into a boutique hotel called El Angel Azul.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Sir Francis Drake and Queen Elizabeth I Made England a Global Power
description: Laurence Bergreen’s rollicking “In Search of a Kingdom” looks at the highly profitable relationship between a pirate and the first Queen Elizabeth.

title: Democrats Are Anxious About 2022 — and 2024
description: The fretting starts with the party’s declining share of the Hispanic vote, but it doesn’t end there.
content: In the wake of the 2020 election, Democratic strategists are worried — very worried — about the future of the Hispanic vote. One in 10 Latinos who supported Hillary Clinton in 2016 switched to Donald Trump in 2020.
